questions.question: There is clearly something wrong with her.
questions.description: Adverbs are words that indicate ideas such as time, place, manner and frequency.

questions.question: She is my teacher but she is also my friend.
questions.description: But is a conjunction and friend is a noun. Also is the adverb.

questions.question: He always wears a coat, even in summer.
questions.description: Wears is a verb and summer is a noun. Always is the adverb.

questions.question: He often comes and stays with us.
questions.description: With is a preposition and is a conjunction often is an adverb of frequency

questions.question: I am going to Venice today.
You have definitely been a great help.
questions.description: Words ending in -ly are usually adverbs note that there are a few exceptions to this rule.

questions.question: This time next week, I will be happily working in my garden.
questions.description: Next is an adjective garden is a noun happily is the adverb.

questions.question: I donâ€™t think the repair has been properly done.
questions.description: Properly is an adverb indicating manner.

questions.question: I am really sorry for disturbing you.
questions.description: Really is an adverb indicating manner.

questions.question: We went to bed early.
questions.description: Words indicating time, place, manner, frequency, condition etc., are all adverbs.

questions.question: The war seriously affected oil prices.
She must sometimes have wanted to run away.
questions.description: Words indicating time and frequency are adverbs.
